LEBED CentralAero-Hydrodynamical Institute, Zjukovsky-3, Moscow District 140160, USSR Received 6 July 1989; in final form 28 October 1989 A description of a rarefied gas is presented using the method of pair functions. The conception of pair distribution functions is introduced and a heuristical derivation of the equations for pair functions is presented. Unlike the situation with the traditional Boltzmann equation, the hypothesis of molecular chaos was not used during the derivation of the equations for pair functions. The Boltzmann kinetic equation suffers from the defect that during its derivation the hypothesis of molecular chaos is assumed, which presupposes the statistical independence of the colliding particles. This paper presents a method which does not involve the hypothesis of molecular chaos and this fact makes it possible to estimate the error introduced by the hypothesis into the kinetic and hydrodynamic equations. We consider a rarefied homogeneous gas, containing structureless particles without outside disturbance. The gas is assumed to be rarefied if the time t between two collisions is much greater than the characteristic collision time r~ (triple collisions may be neglected). Our study is limited by the case r << ~, where ~ is the characteristic time scale of the flow. Particles move in such a gas without any interaction for most of the time. In the time interval between two collisions the particle is in a diverging phase with respect to the particle it has collided with and in an approaching phase with respect to the next particle it is to collide with. The method is based on division of all the gas particles into approaching and divergent pairs. The production of a pair of divergent particles is identical with the termination of their collision process, and the disappearance of the pair is identical with the collision of at least one of the particles of the pair with a third particle. In much the same way one may isolate pairs of approaching particles in the gas. The disappearance of the pair of particles is identical with the beginning of the interaction between the particles. The production of the pair is identified with the termination of the interaction of both particles with third particles. Some particles at certain times may have no pair, i.e. the particle at this instant is not considered to be approaching another particles until the particle it is to collide with is produced. This problem will not be discussed in this study and such situations will be ignored.
